summary: This is an FBI Daily News Briefing summarizing a Wall Street Journal report that JPMorgan Chase internally flagged Jeffrey Epstein's large cash withdrawals in 2006, two years before his 2008 conviction. The briefing references lawsuits alleging the bank facilitated Epstein's sex trafficking by processing suspicious transactions.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the report; his large cash withdrawals from JPMorgan in 2006 were internally flagged by the bank. He was convicted in 2008 and died in jail in 2019.

persons.name: Safdar
persons.context: Co-author of the Wall Street Journal article cited in the FBI briefing.

persons.name: Benoit
persons.context: Co-author of the Wall Street Journal article cited in the FBI briefing.

persons.name: Stempel
persons.context: Reporter for Reuters who also covered the story mentioned in the briefing.

connections.description: Epstein was a client of JPMorgan, which processed his large cash withdrawals and wire transfers. The bank's risk-management team flagged his activity in 2006.

events.title: JPMorgan flags Epstein's withdrawals
events.description: JPMorgan Chase's risk-management team internally noted that Jeffrey Epstein was routinely making large cash withdrawals of $40,000 to $80,000 several times a month, totaling over $750,000 a year.

events.title: Epstein first charged with a sex crime
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was first charged with a sex crime.

events.title: Epstein's guilty plea
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pleaded guilty to solicitation of prostitution with a minor and spent about 13 months in prison.

events.title: JPMorgan closes Epstein's accounts
events.description: JPMorgan Chase states it closed Jeffrey Epstein's accounts.

events.title: Epstein's death in jail
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died in jail of an apparent suicide while awaiting trial on federal sex-trafficking charges.

events.title: US Virgin Islands sues JPMorgan
events.description: The U.S. Virgin Islands sued JPMorgan late last year in a Manhattan federal court, alleging the bank facilitated Epstein's sex trafficking.

keyFacts: JPMorgan Chase employees internally flagged Jeffrey Epstein's large cash withdrawals (typically $40,000-$80,000 several times a month) in 2006, two years before his 2008 conviction.
The U.S. Virgin Islands alleges in a lawsuit that JPMorgan facilitated Epstein's sex trafficking by processing transactions used to pay victims.
An unnamed woman who accused Epstein of sexual abuse has also filed a lawsuit accusing JPMorgan of failing to monitor his transactions.
Epstein withdrew over $750,000 a year in cash from JPMorgan at the time his activity was flagged.
JPMorgan continued providing banking services to Epstein until 2013, five years after his conviction.
